en.description: This presentation will demonstrate how to develop and distribute a simple permission framework for managing access to Arches resources based on resource attributes such as geometry or lifecycle state. Attribute based permissions is a fairly common business requirement that would be cumbersome to implement in Arches, but not difficult to implement by leveraging pluggable permission frameworks. The intended audience is any developer interested in extending Arches with attribute based permissions or designing their own permission framework.
en.name: Attribute Based Permissions in Arches

en.value: Attribute Based Permissions in Arches

This presentation will demonstrate how to develop and distribute a simple permission framework for managing access to Arches resources based on resource attributes such as geometry or lifecycle state. Attribute based permissions is a fairly common business requirement that would be cumbersome to implement in Arches, but not difficult to implement by leveraging pluggable permission frameworks. The intended audience is any developer interested in extending Arches with attribute based permissions or designing their own permission framework.

en.description: This presentation will outline novel search features introduced in the RASColls Arches Application that may inform how search could be improved in future versions of Arches. These include search across resource relationships, a performant means of rendering a full search result set in a vector tile layer using MapLibre, and a means of performing a search against hierarchical spatial features such as city, state, and national boundaries. The intended audience would be developers interested in authoring their own Vue plugin for searching and visualizing resource data, as well as those developers curious about how Arches search might be improved.
en.name: Developing a Custom Search Plugin to Manage Reference and Sample Collections in Arches

resourceinstance.name: Developing a Custom Search Plugin to Manage Reference and Sample Collections in Arches

en.value: Developing a Custom Search Plugin to Manage Reference and Sample Collections in Arches

en.description:
This presentation will show how the Arches Bulk Data Manager can be used to import data from an Esri service as part of a field data collection workflow.

Field data collection is an important part of data management for many organizations, and often for those organizations that already have established Esri infrastructure. In this presentation, I would like show how the Bulk Data Manager can be used to collect field data using a data collection app such as Survey123. Since the Bulk Data Manager was first introduced in v.6.1, the patterns to import data have matured and become easier to implement. During my presentation, I hope to encourage other developers to write their own custom ETL modules.

The intended audience would be developers that are interested in importing data from a data collection application using bulk data manager and developing a custom ETL module for the clients.
en.name: Using the Esri Mobile App for Arches Field Data Collection

resourceinstance.name: Using the Esri Mobile App for Arches Field Data Collection

en.value: Using the Esri Mobile App for Arches Field Data Collection

en.description: When users query Arches data, structures shaped like the underlying models present advantages over low-level operations on tiles. Project developers could also find such structures handy in each part of their data-access layer: routes, generic views, filters, validators, paginators, and error handlers. In this talk, we'll share a tool we're using in Arches Lingo and other projects that normalizes Arches data using Django QuerySets, explain what differentiates it from other developments in this area, and sketch out some intended use cases. With fewer motivations for bespoke data-access layers in projects comes a reduced risk of drift against core Arches development. Finally, the approach suggests a way to leverage one Django's strengths: its third-party package ecosystem, much of which is premised on QuerySets as the interface for encapsulating logic.
en.name: Accelerating Arches Application Development with Arches QuerySets

resourceinstance.name: Accelerating Arches Application Development with Arches QuerySets

en.value: Accelerating Arches Application Development with Arches QuerySets

en.description: Integrations between Arches and other front-ends is often spoken about but rarely presented. Using our CIIM middleware software, we have integrated with Arches to display Arches data within a public facing interface. During this talk, we will present our existing integrations, the Arches application that powers it all, and our future plans. Our intended audience is the developer community, but also those interested in using bits of Arches data in a public facing interface, rather than the Arches interface.
en.name: Demonstrating integrations with Arches

en.value: Demonstrating integrations with Arches

Our intended audience is the developer community, but also those interested in using bits of Arches data in a public facing interface, rather than the Arches interface.

en.description: As a service provider, Knowledge Integration are always aiming to further our contributions to core Arches. In this presentation, we aim to show you two new core Arches features: the user preferences model, and an extension to the sort order search component. The intended audience is the developer community who are keen to see these new features, and how they may feature in custom Arches applications.
en.name: A K-Int showcase on new core features

resourceinstance.name: A K-Int showcase on new core features

en.value: A K-Int showcase on new core features

As a service provider, Knowledge Integration are always aiming to further our contributions to core Arches. The intended audience is the developer community who are keen to see these new features, and how they may feature in custom Arches applications.

en.description:
We wish to introduce SPIFFIE (Semantic Pattern Interchange Format Facilitating Integrated Environments), a vendor-neutral framework designed for converting between different semantic data formats. The presentation will demonstrate how SPIFFIE functions as an integration language that bridges multiple modeling environments. I'll showcase the complete workflow: exporting from Arches to sip-creator, converting to RDF-XML, and transforming that output back into Arches tiles via the arches-companion.

This matters because SPIFFIE breaks down silos between different semantic modeling tools and platforms. Models stored in SPIFFIE can be shared in repositories, reused across projects, and adapted by different teams—creating an ecosystem of interchangeable semantic patterns. This approach significantly reduces development time and ensures consistency across implementations.

The intended audience is developers and users who perform data migrations across different platforms or want to construct advanced models using composable semantic patterns. This includes those working with multiple systems beyond just Arches, integration specialists needing to map between different data models, and teams looking to establish libraries of reusable semantic components that work across their technology stack.
en.name: Making your models SPIFFIE

en.value: Making your models SPIFFIE

en.description: The rendering speed of reports in Arches has always been an issue. Rendering times can take anywhere from a few seconds to a few minutes and are often unrelated to the amount of information being presented on screen. This talk will demo work done for the Getty Digital Provenance project where the mandate was to build high-performance reports that could be customized per model. The pattern, developed using pure Vue components and greenfield backend data retrieval, will be presented and will lead to a discussion about wether this could become the basis for reports in Arches 8.
en.name: High Performance Reporting in Arches using Vue

resourceinstance.name: High Performance Reporting in Arches using Vue

en.value: High Performance Reporting in Arches using Vue

en.description: This is a significant enhancement to the Arches CSV import functionality that would allow the import of data into complex models - we have been testing the import using the Getty Provenance Models which have a very high degree of complexity.

en.description: For this lightning talk, I want to give an update to the QGIS plugin; how it can be downloaded (for developers and end-users), help with testing, getting involved in development, latest changes, and the roadmap.
en.name: Updates to the Arches QGIS plugin

resourceinstance.name: Updates to the Arches QGIS plugin

en.description: The current migration strategy, which embeds the SQL in Django Python migration files, makes it difficult to track database objects over time. We're proposing a new strategy to apply SQL migrations for long-lived database objects that should improve DB object tracing and script readability.This will be relevant to any developers that contribute to Core Arches.
en.name: Reworking SQL migration strategy

en.value: Reworking SQL migration strategy

The current migration strategy, which embeds the SQL in Django Python migration files, makes it difficult to track database objects over time. We're proposing a new strategy to apply SQL migrations for long-lived database objects that should improve DB object tracing and script readability.This will be relevant to any developers that contribute to Core Arches.

en.description: I have two items. The first is a proposal to implement natural language queries to interface with Arches search. The second is a prototype and feature proposal to include an auxiliary set of search results that are related to the primary set of search results, e.g. "show me all architects related to buildings build before 1920". Arches presents an amazing opportunity to interface specifically search with LLM's so that what is arguably an inherently esoteric corpus can be more easily interrogated by novel users. Additionally, the resource relationships as a search parameter are not queryable from a frontend UI in core Arches so this is something I'm keen on pushing as it opens up broader and more complex avenues for search. The intended audience within the developer community for both of these subjects are anyone interested in potentially collaborating on these efforts.
en.name: Evolving Search in Arches: an LLM-interpreted NLP proposal and Leveraging Resource relations in Search Results

resourceinstance.name: Evolving Search in Arches: an LLM-interpreted NLP proposal and Leveraging Resource relations in Search Results

en.value: Evolving Search in Arches: an LLM-interpreted NLP proposal and Leveraging Resource relations in Search Results

en.description:
The Mapping Archaeological Heritage in South Asia (MAHSA) project is a collaborative research output focused on documenting the archaeological heritage of Pakistan and Northwest India. A key component of this collaborative research is the implementation of low-cost, digital, scalable and sustainable field surveys. To support this, MAHSA project has developed a field survey system using ODK and KoboToolbox, which is currently in use for data collection.
\n
\nWe are now exploring options to streamline the import of collected field survey data from ODK into Arches. Potential solutions could include another option within Bulk Data Manager to import ODK data or perhaps a dedicated Arches application for this purpose. As this phase is still under discussion, we would like to present this whole process from form development to collected data format and welcome insights and suggestions from developers with similar or comparable data integration experiences.
en.name: Using Open Data Kit (ODK) for Digital Field Surveys: Exploring ODK & Arches Data Integration Solutions

resourceinstance.name: Using Open Data Kit (ODK) for Digital Field Surveys: Exploring ODK & Arches Data Integration Solutions

en.value: Using Open Data Kit (ODK) for Digital Field Surveys: Exploring ODK & Arches Data Integration Solutions

The Mapping Archaeological Heritage in South Asia (MAHSA) project is a collaborative research output focused on documenting the archaeological heritage of Pakistan and Northwest India. A key component of this collaborative research is the implementation of low-cost, digital, scalable and sustainable field surveys. To support this, MAHSA project has developed a field survey system using ODK and KoboToolbox, which is currently in use for data collection.

We are now exploring options to streamline the import of collected field survey data from ODK into Arches. Potential solutions could include another option within Bulk Data Manager to import ODK data or perhaps a dedicated Arches application for this purpose. As this phase is still under discussion, we would like to present this whole process from form development to collected data format and welcome insights and suggestions from developers with similar or comparable data integration experiences.
Dashboarding in Arches

en.description: I intend to give an update about changes in Arches frontend development. This includes changes to requireJS, webpack, cross-stack routing, the arches JavaScript object, and the Arches Vue styleguide. Among other smaller updates.
en.name: Frontend Development and Vue Integration in Arches v8

resourceinstance.name: Frontend Development and Vue Integration in Arches v8
